results.title: Fires within
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Lauren Lloyd, Wallis Nicita and Pathe Entertainment
results.brief_description: When husband and wife Nestor (Jimmy Smits) and Isabel (Greta Scacchi) are reunited after Nestor is freed from jail for serving a 10 year term as a political prisoner they both find it hard to existence as husband and wife, living in Miami’s Little Havana. The community are eager for Nestor to resume his role as spokesperson for atrocities perpetrated by the Cuban government. His wife, Isabel (Greta Scacchi), does not want their lives or their families in Cuba sacrificed to the greater cause of freedom of expression. Isabel has also found love in the arms of the American fisherman who saved her and her daughter when they nearly drowned fleeing Cuba, and like her husband, she too must make a choice between her priorities as a lover, and as a wife and mother. Cast also includes Vincent D’Onofrio.

results.title: Braindead = Dead alive (D)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jackson, Jim Booth and Wingnut Films
results.brief_description: New Zealand director Peter Jackson has aptly described “Braindead’s” anarchic style as splatstick, an outrageous melding of extreme gore and physical humour. While it does go to great lengths to gross you out (you’ll never eat porridge again!), it still finds time to be a rather sweet love story, as well as a titanic Oedipal struggle between mother and son. Set in the latter part of the fifties, “Braindead” concerns momma’s boy Lionel’s (Timothy Balme) feeble attempts to break away from his domineering mother (Elizabeth Moody), while a romance develops between him and local shop girl, Paquita (Diana Penalver). The situation gets messy however when Lionel’s mother is bitten by a strange rat like monkey (captured in a very funny opening sequence) which turns her into one of the living dead. When Lionel’s lecherous uncle Les (Ian Watkin) shows up unexpectedly, all hell breaks loose and soon the place is swarming with zombies.

results.title: The Chess player = Le Joueur D'echecs
results.creator_credit: Raymond Bernard, La Societe des Films Historiques, Photoplay and Thames Television
results.brief_description: Based in historical fact, this silent costume drama is set in 1776 and concerns a German engineer at the Viennese court who created a chess-playing automaton to entertain the Empress Maria Theresa and other royalty. Such was the machine’s track record (Napoleon lost a game to it), suspicion grew that a human being was concealed inside. This material allowed Bernard, whose first film was the sumptuous spectacle ‘Le Miracle Des Loups’(‘The Miracle of the Wolves’) (1929), to again demonstrate his pictorial invention and his knack for not letting spectacle swamp his fine cast of actors. Music plays an important part throughout in sustaining the film’s sweep. This restoration, sourced from prints found in Luxembourg, Germany and Holland, revives the atmospheric original score composed by Henri Rabaud, director of the Paris Conservatoire from 1920 to 1941 and a master of orchestration. Cast includes Pierre Blanchar, Charles Dullin, Edith Jehanne and Camille Bert. From the novel by Henry Dupuy-Mazuel, with full orchestral score. This video edition produced by David Gill and Kevin Brownlow. Music performed by the Symphony Orchestra of Radio-Television-Luxembourg. WITH MUSICAL SOUNDTRACK.

results.title: The Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior
results.creator_credit: Michael Tuchner, Sam Strangis and Capital Cities
results.brief_description: A docu-drama based on the shocking terrorist attack initiated by the French government on the Greenpeace flagship vessel the Rainbow Warrior. The ship which was the centrepiece of the Greenpeace protest against nuclear testing that was being undertaken by the French in the Pacific, was moored in Auckland in August 1986 when it was blown apart by a bomb blast, killing one of its crew. In this dramatization, Sam Neill and Jon Voight play two polar opposites - a hardbitten cop and a eco-activist, respectively - who team up to track down the bombers uncovering an international conspiracy in the process. Cast also includes Bruno Lawrence and Kerry Fox.

results.title: Tom Jones
results.creator_credit: Tony Richardson and Woodfall Film Productions
results.brief_description: Tom Jones (Albert Finney) is found as a newborn in a wealthy squires bed. The illegitimate child grows into a man attractive to all women who happen to pass him in 18th century rural England. Throughout this comic soap opera of love, family and Bruegelesque debauchery, Tom Jones is certainly put through a lot before the lengthy and irreverent film’s conclusion. The plot follows Tom as he is kicked out of home and travels to London, pursued by the woman he loves. There are plenty of adventures along the way, including much feasting, heaving of breasts, sword fighting and a masked ball, just to name a few. The truth of Jones’ parentage is always in question, he doesn’t even know who his real parents are. None of the hardships faced during Tom’s adventure bother him and it’s not often that the smile leaves his attractive face. Based on the classic novel by Henry Fielding, this precursor to ‘Alvin Purple’ is both satirical and bawdy.

results.title: No skin off my ass (E)
results.creator_credit: Bruce LaBruce, Jurgen Bruning and Gaytown Films
results.brief_description: One of the first important works of the “New Queer Cinema”, this acerbic and very witty black comedy is a bout a gay hairdresser (LaBruce) who falls in love with a young skinhead. The skinhead, unsure of how he feels about the hairdresser’s attentions seeks advice from his sister but she is a lesbian separatist filmmaker and not much interested in what goes on between men. Gleefully upsetting the expectations of both the heterosexual and homosexual mainstreams, “No Skin off my Ass” is a film that mixes up gender, sex roles and ideology. LaBruce is uninterested in “positive” images of gay men. Instead he wants to celebrate the absurd irrationalities of desire.

results.title: The Pelican brief
results.creator_credit: Alan Pakula, Pieter Jan Brugge and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A law student (Julia Roberts) turns her suspicions about the deaths of two Supreme Court Justices into a speculative brief that has the potential to rock the highest levels of government. She and a determined investigative reporter (Denzel Washington) want to expose the scandal to the world, the only challenge is to live to tell the tale. This suspenseful film is based on the best-selling thriller by John Grisham.

results.title: Friday the 13th
results.creator_credit: Sean S. Cunningham and Georgetown productions
results.brief_description: At last count Friday the 13th is about to embark into its tenth sequel (it also spun off briefly into a television series) a dubious achievement for a film which was essentially a cheap imitation of John Carpenter’s seminal slasher film Halloween (1978). It also inspired a series of horror films set around commemorative and public holidays (Mothers day, My bloody valentine, April fool’s day, Silent night, deadly night etc..) and launched the careers of Kevin Bacon and horror make-up artist Tom Savini. This however is where all the slasher rules and cliches began. Starting off in 1958, two teenage camp counselors are brutally murdered by an unknown assailant at Camp Crystal lake. Flashing forward 20 years on and a new group of counselors have ascended onto the camp, affectionately dubbed by the wary locals as ‘Camp blood’. Soon enough the body count begins to pile up as the horny teens get dispatched in various gruesome scenarios, all the while ignoring the blatent signs that this is not a good place to be. Cast includes Betsy Palmer, Adrienne King, Harry Crosby, Laurie Bartram, Mark Nelson, Jeannine Taylor, Robbi Morgan

results.title: Lethal weapon 4
results.creator_credit: Richard Donner, Joel Silver and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In this fourth instalment of the Lethal Weapon series Mel Gibson and Danny Glover reprise their roles as Martin Riggs and Roger Murtaugh - a pair of mismatched police detectives who over the course of their relationship have learnt to love and appreciate each other’s contrasting styles. The over-the-top opening sequence establishes what the film has in store - glib throwaway lines, explosive action segments and faint hints at the importance of friendship to these two old buddies. Both Martin and Roger face a period of transition - Martin is to become a father (with Internal Affairs officer Lorna Cole - played by Rene Russo) whilst Roger is to become a grandfather. And the bad guys? Well represented by the Chinese triads who are involved with an illegal people-smuggling ring. Highlights of this film are the fight sequences, featuring Asian star Jet Li, staged by Hong Kong director Corey Yuen. Chris Rock (utilising his signature frenetic comedic shtick) plays a new cop on the block with unstinting passion for his job.

results.title: Funny games [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Michael Haneke, Veit Heiduschka and Wega Film
results.brief_description: It is the beginning of the summer holidays and a rich Austrian family prepare to begin their vacation at their rural estate. Their peace is shattered however when two seemingly nice young men arrive at their door and begin a series of cruel and violent games which culminate in torture and murder. Austrian director Michael Haneke directed a trilogy of films in the 1990s, (“The Seventh Continent”, “71 Fragments for a Chronology of Chance” and “Benny’s Video”) which all examined the relationship between violence, crime, media and class. But “Funny Games” takes Haneke’s critical examination one step further by this time implicating “us” - the audience - in his condemnation of modern mass media. Harrowing, intensely disturbing and frightening, “Funny Games” exploits our voyeuristic thrill in watching mayhem and violence. By refusing to either conform to the established conventions of the horror/thriller genre or to the simplistic explanations and sociology of most realist art-house cinema, Haneke instead indicts the modern cinema audience for not only our acceptance of film violence but our own complicity in encouraging the escalation of a violent and alienated society. This is a film that will start arguments. Countering the dominance of post-modern theories which argue that contemporary cinema audiences are media-literate and ironically resistant to manipulation, Haneke instead responds with a film that reinstates the necessity of the ethical and committed intellectual. Whatever intellectual position one takes to this film - and make no mistake, Haneke demands intellectual engagement as a moral imperative - this is not a film that can be easily dismissed. A film for which the adjective “shocking” is not hyperbole. This film is truly frightening. Cast includes Susanne Lothar and Franc Geiring. In German with English subtitles.

description_for_label: It is the beginning of the summer holidays and a rich Austrian family prepare to begin their vacation at their rural estate. Their peace is shattered however when two seemingly nice young men arrive at their door and begin a series of cruel and violent games which culminate in torture and murder. Austrian director Michael Haneke directed a trilogy of films in the 1990s, (“The Seventh Continent”, “71 Fragments for a Chronology of Chance” and “Benny’s Video”) which all examined the relationship between violence, crime, media and class. But “Funny Games” takes Haneke’s critical examination one step further by this time implicating “us” - the audience - in his condemnation of modern mass media. Harrowing, intensely disturbing and frightening, “Funny Games” exploits our voyeuristic thrill in watching mayhem and violence. By refusing to either conform to the established conventions of the horror/thriller genre or to the simplistic explanations and sociology of most realist art-house cinema, Haneke instead indicts the modern cinema audience for not only our acceptance of film violence but our own complicity in encouraging the escalation of a violent and alienated society. This is a film that will start arguments.
